titleStmt.title: The famous and delightful history of the golden eagle giving an account of how Albertus, King of Arragon, being at the point of death, was advised to procure the golden eagle, kept by the Queen of Ivyland, for his recovery: how his three sons went in search of that adventure, and what befel them on the way; how Innocentine the youngest, prevailed, and got the golden eagle, with the advice his horse gave him: how his two brothers robbed him of the eagle, and accused him to the King, for which he narrowly escaped death, being utterly disgraced, until the Queen arrived, who restored him to favour, and then married him, &c. with many other adventures, both pleasant and profitable. Licens'd and entered according to order.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: The famous and delightful history of the golden eagle giving an account of how Albertus, King of Arragon, being at the point of death, was advised to procure the golden eagle, kept by the Queen of Ivyland, for his recovery: how his three sons went in search of that adventure, and what befel them on the way; how Innocentine the youngest, prevailed, and got the golden eagle, with the advice his horse gave him: how his two brothers robbed him of the eagle, and accused him to the King, for which he narrowly escaped death, being utterly disgraced, until the Queen arrived, who restored him to favour, and then married him, &c. with many other adventures, both pleasant and profitable. Licens'd and entered according to order.

Running title reads: The history of the golden eagle.
Reproduction of the original in the Bodleian Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Famous and Delightful HISTORY OF The Golden Eagle:

Giving an Account how Albertus, King of Arragon, being at the Point of Death, was advi≈øed to procure the Golden Eag ‚Ä¢ e, kept by the Queen of Ivyland, for his Recovery: How his three Sons went in ≈øearch of that Adventure, and what befel them on the way; how Innocentine the younge≈øt, prevailed, and got the Golden Eagle, with the Advice his Hor≈øe gave him: How his two Brothers robbed him of the Eagle, and accu≈øed him to the King, for which he narrowly e≈øcaped Death, being utterly Di≈øgraced, until the Queen arrived, who re≈øtored him to Favour, and then married him, &c. with many other Adventures, both Plea≈øant and Profitable.

figure.figDesc: woodcut of man in bed, four men standing nearby

div.p: Licens'd and Ente ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d acco ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing to O ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r.
London: Printed by and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ and ≈øold „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Bo ‚Ä¢ k≈øellers.

figure.figDesc: woodcut of small castle and several people

div.head: The Hi≈øtory of the Golden Eagle, &c.
Chap. I.

argument.p: How Albertus King of Arragon, falling into a langui≈øhing Di≈øea≈øe, was advi≈øed by his Phi≈øitians to provide for Death; and the News being ≈øpread over the Country, many Magicians came to him, who told him, that if he could recover the Golden Eagle from the Queen of Ivyland, he ≈øhould que≈øtionle≈øs recover his Health, &c.

div.p: ALbertus having of late buried the Soul of his Life Ly≈øimena, his mo≈øt indulgent Queen, fell into extream Melancholy, which as it is commonly the Parent of all Di≈øea≈øes, ≈øo it brought him into a mo≈øt tedious and langui≈øhing Sickne≈øs, which cau≈øed him to make Moan both Day and Night; witne≈øs the bitter Groans, and pa≈ø≈øionate Expre≈ø≈øions for the lo≈øs of his departed Con≈øort: at la≈øt, being importuned by ≈øeveral of his Nobles, and hourly intreated by his three Sons, Philonzo, Cruentius and Innocentine, he con≈øented to ≈øend for the chiefe≈øt Doctros in tho≈øe Parts, to con≈øult about the State and Welfare of his Body; which Doctors being arrived, were pre≈øently conducted to the King's Chamber, at who≈øe ≈øight the King broke out into the≈øe ≈øad Expre≈ø≈øions:

Ye are come to look upon a delining King; ye may endeavour to u≈øe your Skills, but I am confident your Labour will be lost. Alas, my Di≈øea≈øe is too inward to be found out; and if ye Cure me, it must be more by Miracle than Skill: If ye can Cure an almo≈øt broken Heart, or repair my half-decayed Lungs, or re≈øtore my near-wa≈øted Breath, then draw near: But, alas, my Ly≈øimena‚Äî And there his Sighs denying him liberty of Speech, he made Signs to be no more troubled, and turning from the Company, and almo≈øt from his own Sen≈øes, he groaned him≈øelf into a deep Melancholy.

The Doctors as yet being not thoroughly acquainted with his Di≈øea≈øe, verily ≈øuppo≈øed him departing but it proved otherwi≈øe; for his Sons, and the re≈øt of the Nobility informing
the Doctors of his Grief, de≈øired them to u≈øe their be≈øt Endenvours for his Recovery; which accordingly they did, but finding little hopes of Life, in re≈øpect that the Di≈øtemper of his Mind bad ≈øo much impaired the Temper of his body, they only pre≈øcribed him Cordials, which indeed ≈øomething revived and exhilerated his Spirits, but could not give the lea≈øt hopes of Life, in re≈øpect that Nature was much extenuated and weakened by his extraordinary Melancholy.

The King, whether le≈øs in≈øen≈øible of his Di≈øea≈øe, or ≈øomewhat more enlivened by the Pre≈øcriptions of the Doctors, de≈øires two of the able≈øt of them to be brought unto him, of whem he demanded their free and ab≈øolute Opinions; The Doctors after a ≈øhort Pau≈øe, who having more re≈øpect to Con≈øcience than Gain, told him that they might prolong, but not Cure; and being about to proceed into further Di≈øcour≈øe, there ≈øuddenly came in ≈øome of the Nobility, and whi≈øpered with one of the Doctors, which the King perceiving, demanded the Cau≈øe; to which the Nobility replyed, That there were newly arrived ≈øeveral Magicians, who hearing of his Maje≈øty's Di≈øtemper, came out of affectionate Duty to imploy their Skill for his Recovery; the King hearing this, di≈ømi≈øt the Doctors, and admitted the Magicians, who being entred, and after the Performance of their ≈øeveral Duties, applyed them≈øelves in this manner:

Mo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Renowned Sir, We the most humble of all your Servants, being by Report informed of your Maje≈øty's heavy and grievous Di≈øea≈øe, have by our Indu≈øtry found out a Means (which though a may ≈øeem impo≈ø≈øible to your Maje≈øty) will without que≈øtion re≈øtore you to your former Health; which means (craving the Favour of your Maje≈øty's Patience) we ≈øhall forthwith di≈øcover: Know then, most excellent Prince, that under the Juri≈ødiction of Agrippina, that most famous and invincible Queen of Ivyland, there is a Golden Eagle, in whom there is a ≈øecret and infallible Remedy for your Di≈øea≈øe; therefore if any of tho≈øe Heroick Spirits which are belonging to your Maje≈øty, will endeavour to procure this Eagle, your Maje≈øty's Life will que≈øtionle≈øs be pre≈øerved: We ≈øhall not therefore trouble your Maje≈øty's Ears with
any further Relation, but leave your Maje≈øty to the Pro≈øecution of what we have related; only we will be bold to de≈øire your Maje≈øty not to be doubtful, for he that your Maje≈øty ≈øhall least re≈øpect or expect, ≈øhall perform this dangerous and almost impo≈ø≈øible De≈øign; ≈øo we leave your Maje≈øty to your most ≈øerious Con≈øiderations.

div.head: Chap. II.

argument.p: The Magicians being gone, the King ≈øends for his three Sons, and acquaints them with what the Magicians had told him, proffering to divide his E≈øtate between them, if they could recover the Eagle from the Queen of Ivyland, wi≈øhing them to take what Trea≈øure they would for their Occa≈øions.

div.p:
THe Magicians being departed, the King immediately gave Command that his three Sons ≈øhould come unto him; they as diligent to obey, as he was willing to command, forthwith pre≈øented them≈øelves before him. The King after ≈øome Di≈øcour≈øe, told them now his Days were near fini≈øhed, and Nature began ≈øo much to decline in him, that he was pa≈øt the Skill of Doctors; therefore let me advi≈øe you, as a dying Father, that as ye were born Brothers in Nature, ≈øo to continue in Affection. Sir, replyed the Elde≈øt, if it plea≈øe the Gods to di≈øpo≈øe of you to Death, we must labour for that Portion of Content which may be proportionable to our Sorrows; for the Decrees of Fate are not to be re≈øi≈øted; and one Rea≈øon tells us, that what we cannot remedy, we must patiently endure: But for my part (and I dare ≈øay as much for my Brothers) I would willingly hazard my Life for the Prolongation of yours. Sir, I hope that you will plea≈øe to apprehend that the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions which are like to fall to us after your Death, do not any way incite us either to hope, or wi≈øh for it. With that, the two other Brothers not able to contain any longer; de≈øired their Father to imploy them in any thing whereby they might expre≈øs their Obedience to him. To which the King (joyful to ≈øee their pa≈ø≈øionate Obedience) replyed, That there was but one way to ≈øave his Life, which was to do according to the Directions of the Magicians, who informed him, that if he could by any means recover the Golden
Eagle from the Queen of Ivyland, that then he ≈øhould be re≈øtored to his former Health; But, ≈øays he, I find it a thing impo≈ø≈øible, therefore I ≈øhall not trouble my≈øelf with the Thoughts of obtaining it, for the Queen is of that Power and Strength, that if I ≈øhould pre≈øwade any to attempt it, I ≈øhould be guilty of their Deaths, and ≈øo depart this World with a burthen'd Con≈øcience; But, my Sons, I am very well content to leave tho≈øe Slaveries which are Attendants to a Crown; I can only pray for you, and that's my uttermo≈øt.

Before the King had made an end of his intended Di≈øcour≈øe, his Sons interrupted him with Sighs, that floated in Tears, and as well as their Sorrows would permit, they in mo≈øt humble manner de≈øired the King to grant them a Boon before his Departure; to which the King plea≈øingly replyed, Enjoy your De≈øires, provided ye ask what is nece≈ø≈øary for me to give; Speak, what is your Boon? to which they replyed, Renowned Sir, It was not long ≈øince you were plea≈øed to ble≈øs our Ears with the Di≈øcour≈øe of the Magicians, who have a≈ø≈øured both you and us, that if the Golden Eagle can be recovered, your Health ≈øhall be renewed; Then know, Sir, that as our Bodies are Derivatives from you, ≈øo they are by all Laws, what≈øoever, to be at your Di≈øpo≈øing; and here we pre≈øent our≈øelves before you, and protest with all our Souls to hazard, nay lo≈øe our Lives, but we will obtain the Eagle; for you know, Sir, that Re≈øolution backt with obedient Affections, knows no Impo≈ø≈øibilities; Sir, we ≈øhall not ari≈øe from our Knees till you have granted our Request, and at your Royal Con≈øent, we will forthwith fly into Action.

The King ≈øeeing them thus re≈øolved, thought it ≈øuperfluous to endeavour to di≈øcour≈øe them out of their Re≈øolutions, but told them, that ≈øince their Obedience made them ≈øo ready to undertake ≈øo great a Hazard, his Affections ≈øhould prompt him, at their Return, to divide all his Trea≈øure (which at that time was very great) among≈øt them; in the mean time he advi≈øed them to provide them≈øelves with what Money they would, and all other Aceutrements nece≈ø≈øary for their Adventure, which they accordingly did.

div.head: Chap. III.

argument.p: How the King's three Sons provided for their Journy, and took leave of their Father and departed, and what happened between them in their Journy.

div.p: THe three Brothers having prepared them≈øelves for their Journey, came in humble manner to take leave of the King, whom they found, as formerly, very much troubled with Melancholy; but the Elde≈øt addre≈ø≈øing him≈øelf unto him, began in this manner:

Royal Sir, We your mo≈øt obedient Sons, in order to our dear Affections, more than your Royal Command, pre≈øent our ≈øelves to crave your Ble≈ø≈øing upon us, and our De≈øigns, before our Departure, not de≈øpairing of our De≈øires, we humbly crave.‚Äî The King looking upon them with a Countenance that imported unexpre≈ø≈øible Grief for their Departure, rai≈øed him≈øelf upon his Pillow, and with a ≈øtretched out Arm gave them his Ble≈ø≈øing, withal advi≈øing them as they were Brothers in Nature, ≈øo to continue Brothers in Affection, and to have a care that neither Envy nor Ambition, or ambtious Envy, ≈øhould rai≈øe a factious Difference among≈øt them, but as they departed Brothers, and ≈øo con≈øequently Friends, ≈øo they ≈øhould adventure and return in the like Amity they departed; And ≈øo the greate≈øt Ble≈ø≈øing that a dying Father can be≈øtow upon his Departing Children, accompany you; but before you go, let m ‚Ä¢ as a Father, advi≈øe you of two things; The one is, the Plea≈øure of the Gods by the neglect of your. Duty to them; the other is, The Danger of evil Company, which may ≈øeduce you to many Inconveniences; and ≈øo farewel‚ñ™ what I want in Words, I ≈øhall ≈øupply in Thoughts.

Thus the≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ e Brothers having received the Sum of their De≈øires, depa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ from the Pre≈øence of their Father, and ≈øo taking leave of their Friends at Court, departed: At la≈øt, having journied three Days, they came by a mi≈øtake of thou Way into a great Wood, where being in a Wilderne≈øs of Doubt, they con≈øulted what was be≈øt to do; Philonzo, the elder Brother, beginning already to find the Incumbrances of Travel. expre≈øt him≈øelf to the others, as follows:

We ≈øee, dear Brothers, the many Troubles the want of Con≈øideration brings upon us; we have (as I have weighed in my more ≈øerious Thoughts) undertaken a mo≈øt dangerous, trouble≈øome, and almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible De≈øign; To prevent this, how ≈øhall we advi≈øe? If we ≈øhould return home, we ≈øhould turn our noble Undertakings to Ignominy and Shame; and if we proceed, without que≈øtion we ≈øhall lo≈øe our Lives; and what will the World ≈øay but this, They have the Effect of their Ra≈øhne≈øs; for the more dangerous a De≈øign is, the more it ought to be di≈øcu≈øt; but they that like Phaeton, mount at Impo≈ø≈øibilities, ≈øhall at la≈øt fall like him with Shame and Di≈øhonour; therefore, Brothers, let me hear your Advice. To which Cruentius, the ≈øecond Brother, replied,

'Tis true, ra≈øh Beginnings have mo≈øt commonly fatal Conclu≈øions: For my part, as yet I never weighed the Bu≈øine≈øs, nor the Danger, but altogether depended upon your Judgment as an Oracle, not dreaming but you had known the Difficulty of the Bu≈øine≈øs: But ≈øtay now, I better con≈øider the Matter, methinks it ≈øhould not be ≈øo difficult, for ≈øure we three can conquer one Eagle; for, Brother, you ≈øhall catch her, and I will warrant you my Brother and I will hold her; but where ≈øhall we find her? Fie, Brother, quoth Philonzo, I ≈øee you as much err in the Matter, as I did in the Manner of the Bu≈øine≈øs. This Eagle is a Bird kept for her Soveraignty in a great City walled round with Bra≈øs, pallizado'd with Iron, guarded with Lyons and Dragons, and commanded by Gyants, and we mu≈øt, before we come to this City, encounter with ≈øeveral Knights, which attend purpo≈øely for ≈øuch Attempters as we mu≈øt be: Many have attempted, but never any as yet returned to tell the manner of their Attempts; therefore, Brother, the Bu≈øine≈øs is of more Intricacy than you imagine. O mon≈øtrous, cry'd Cruentius, I am more than half dead already with the Relation, tall no more of it: What, Dragons and Bears, Lyons and Giants, Brazen Walls and Iron Pallizadoes? Oh how am I thundred to Death! Attempt it, who will, for my part I'll ≈øtarve here rather han be eaten with Bears, and Lyons, and Dragons, and ‚Äî Oh horrible
Giants, not I. Brother Innocentine, What ≈øaye≈øt thou to the≈øe terrible things? what, art not afraid? Well I have Fear enough for you both, but, good Brother, ≈øpeak. To which Innocentine the younger undauntedly replied:

As I am younge≈øt in Years, ≈øo I am la≈øt in Speech, and I could wi≈øh I might be the lea≈øt; but in re≈øpect I am to make an≈øwer to both your Demands, I mu≈øt a little exerci≈øe your Patience: 'Tis true, the Danger is great, therefore the more noble; but had you, my Brethren, according to my Father's Advice, importuned the Gods before you had undertaken this great De≈øign, que≈øtionle≈øs the one had not been filled with Doubts, nor the other with Fears, nor I with Shame for you both; you ≈øeem to be as much di≈øplea≈øed at my Words, as I am at your Actions; ≈øhall we begin to tire, before we begin to do? For Shame, let not the World have this Advantage of our Reputations: If we return home, we mu≈øt expect to undergo a Di≈øgrace wor≈øe than Death; If we dye, we dye in high Attempts; who knows but the Gods may ≈øhew extraordinary Favours, and ≈ømile at our De≈øigns, being we do it for our dear Father's Life? If the wor≈øt come to the wor≈øt, we can but dye, and we had better do ≈øo than live as if we lived not: but I perceive my Di≈øcour≈øe offends, I will therefore be ≈øilent.

div.head: Chap. IV.

argument.p: How Philonzo and Cruentius hearing the Di≈øcour≈øe of their younger' Brother Innocentine, robb'd him of his Trea≈øure, and left him bound in a Wood, where they afterwards lost them≈øelves.

div.p:
CRuentius hearing his Brother's Di≈øcour≈øe, which was contrary to his Expectations, told him that he was a very ra≈øh Boy, and under≈øtood not what he ≈øpoke; For, ≈øays he, ≈øhall we ca≈øt away our Lives, becau≈øe the World ≈øhould ≈øay we died nobly? Brother, ≈øays he to Philonzo, are we bound to be Fools becau≈øe he's mad? No, let's leave him to the Thoughts of Honour, whil≈øt you and I con≈øult what's be≈øt to do; ≈øo walking a di≈øtance from him, they ≈øate down, and
began thus to expre≈øs them≈øelves: Brother Cruentius, I have both in this ≈øhort time con≈øidered the Shame and the Danger, let us endeavour to ha≈øte to Me≈øemptronia, a City which I am ≈øure cannot be far from this Place, where we may refre≈øh our≈øelves, and have further Di≈øcour≈øe. But what ≈øhall we do, replied Cruentius, with you fooli≈øh Boy? you perceive how refractory and incon≈øiderate he is, and makes ≈ølight of that Danger which we know to be very great: If we leave him, que≈øtionle≈øs he will return home and incen≈øe the King again≈øt us; what we ≈øhall do in this I know not, but leave it to your Di≈øcretion. Let's force him with us, quoth Philonzo, and make him do according to our Wills; if not, we will threaten to kill him. No, quoth Cruentius, that cannot be, for then he will pry into all our Actions, and make a Di≈øcovery at our Returns; but, Brother, quoth he, our Bu≈øine≈øs requires ha≈øte, let us therefore take away his Trea≈øure, and bind him, and leave him in the Wood; for it's better one peri≈øh than two: and if the wor≈øt comes to the wor≈øt, that he ≈øhould be unloo≈øed and return home, we know at our return how to per≈øwade that what he has related is only Lies to di≈øgrace us, and by that means to in≈øinnuate the more into Favour him≈øelf, and injure us. I like this Advice well, quoth Philonzo; let us quickly put it in Execution, for the Night ha≈øtens; with that returning to Innocentine, they asked him, what he intended to do; who replied, What they did not. And ≈øo you ≈øhall, quoth Cruentius; and ≈øo both running together laid hold on him, and without hearing him ≈øpeak, bound him, and took away his Trea≈øure, and turning his Hor≈øe loo≈øe to range in the Woods they departed. Thus ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y poor Innocentine mi≈øerably bound, in≈øomuch, that the ≈øwelling of his Hands and Feet made him mo≈øt ≈øadly lament his grievous Tortures: But Philonzo and Cruentius having rambled up and down the Wood for the ≈øpace of two Hours, could by no means find the Way out, in≈øomuch that they de≈øpair'd of travelling any further that Night, but having not rode a Flight≈øhot further, it happened that a Dog having lo≈øt his Ma≈øter, came fawning on Cruentius, who pre≈øently laid hold of him,
and tying him in a String, followed the Dog, who forthwith brought them out of the Wood, and pre≈øently after to a Shepherd's Hou≈øe where the Dog received pre≈øent Entertainment; but Philonzo and Cruentius none, where we ≈øhall for a time leave them, and return to Innocentine, whom they left bound in the Wood.

div.head: Chap. V.

argument.p: How Innocentine was unbound by an Hermet, and how afterwards he ≈øaved a beautiful Lady from Ravi≈øhment, and how the Lady requited him.

div.p:
INnocentine being fa≈øt bound by his unnatural Brothers, lay till the Approach of the Evening in a mo≈øt mi≈øerable Condition, till at la≈øt a Hermet coming from his Cell, to take the Cool of the Evening, heard the Groans of poor Innocentine, and being moved with Pity, he addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf to the place (I may well ≈øay) of Groans, where being come, his Eyes ≈øaw, what his Heart pitied, his Heart pitied what his Hand relieved; for he forthwith conducted him to his Cell, and made ≈øuch Preparations for him as his. Nece≈ø≈øity required, ≈øo that the next Morning he was in a Condition to travel; but the Hermit viewing his Gue≈øt, read in his Countenance the Characters of a noble and ingenious Di≈øpo≈øition, ob≈øerving by his Deportment, that he was not a Man of ordinary Education, be≈øides being led by his own Inclinations, he acco≈øts his Sra ‚Ä¢
ger in this manner:

Sir, I perceive that Youth and Education prompts you to Ba≈øhfulne≈øs, and your Ba≈øhfulne≈øs hinders the Liberty of your Speech, I therefore heartily intreat you to inform me of your pre≈øent Condition, and what I want in Power, I will ≈øupply in Prayer for you; I will not ≈øtand to trouble you to relate the Misfortunes, it is enough, and too much that I ≈øaw them, only tell me which Way you intend to ≈øteer, and what you want.

Innocentine all this while amazed at the Courte≈øie of the Hermit, knew not pre≈øently what to an≈øwer, but as well as
his late Di≈øtemper, attended with a multitude of Thoughts, would permit, he thus replied:

Mo≈øt charitable Father, I could grieve that I was ≈øorry for my la≈øt Misfortune, in re≈øpect that the Happine≈øs of your Acquaintance is derived from it, I'll not trouble your Patience with the di≈øcou≈øe of my Misfortune; only in ≈øhort, I am going upon a De≈øign to ≈øave the Life of a renowned King, but this Misfortune hath put me out of a Capacity to follow my Intentions. Come, ≈øays the Hermit, I know your Di≈øea≈øe, I'll be your Phy≈øician, take this Cordial, giving him a bag of Gold and Jewels, and return no complimental An≈øwer, for I am bound to do it; and if you want a Steed, I have one for you which this very Day ≈øtragled hither, pray take him and u≈øe him as your own; but for this Sword, which I intend for your u≈øe, pray return it if you live, if not, conceal the Virtue, for it will pre≈øerve you again≈øt all Enchantments, which are now very common to my woful Experience, neither need you fear, whom you encounter with it, for you ≈øhall not want ≈øucce≈øs.

Innocentine not a little rejoyced at what the Hermit had told him, de≈øired liberty to depart, in order to which the Hermit conducted him to his Hor≈øe; but it fell out that the Hor≈øe was his own, which he thought his Brothers had carried away with them; the Hermit ob≈øerving him look ≈øo ≈øtrictly upon the Hor≈øe, told him that he could not promi≈øe him the like Service from the Hor≈øe, as he did from the Sword; No, Sir, quoth Innocentine, I believe I am better acquainted with the Hor≈øe than you, for Ye≈øterday he was mine, till taken from me by Misfortune: but however, I cannot but expre≈øs my hearty Thanks to you, and at my return you ≈øhall know more of me; in the mean time, let Peace abide with you; let me only beg your Directions to Green Ivyland, for I am altogether a Stranger in the≈øe Parts. Your ready way, quoth the Hermit, is to go to Me≈øemptronia, a City about three Leagues from hence, the way is direct through ≈øeveral Villages, where you may at your plea≈øure enquire;
but there is a Forre≈øt which lies between a little Town called Corumbus and Me≈øemptronia, where you mu≈øt have a careful Eye, lea≈øt you be ≈øet upon before you can provide for Re≈øi≈øtance; this is all that I can advi≈øe you, and ≈øo farewel.

Mo≈øt noble and renowned Knight, my late Fright hath ≈øo di≈øordered my thoughts, that for the pre≈øent I cannot return you tho≈øe Thanks which are due to your Merits; but if you plea≈øe to add one Favour more to the re≈øt, which is to conduct me to my poor Habitation (from which place tho≈øe Villians you ≈øaw, having ≈øurprized me in a ≈øolitary Walk, dragg'd me) you will very much increa≈øe my Happine≈øs. To which Reque≈øt Innocentine conde≈øcended, and in ≈øhort time came to the Place where he found a welcome Entertainment: So after many Ceremonies pa≈øt between them, the Lady reque≈øted
to know what his Name and Birth was; to which Innocentine replied, So much confidence have I of your Worth, that I will not keep the lea≈øt of my thoughts from you; ≈øo compo≈øing him≈øelf, he told her his Name, Birth and De≈øign, and likewi≈øe told her how his Brothers had dealt with him, which he was confident were tho≈øe whieh would have ravi≈øhed her, had not he by Providence prevented them; the Lady hearing his Relation, was much a≈øtoni≈øhed, but at la≈øt recalling her≈øelf from her Admiration, proceeded as follows:

figure.figDesc: woodcut of small castle and several people

div.head: Chap. VI.

argument.p: How Philonzo and Cruentius came to th ‚Ä¢ Shepherd's Hou≈øe, but could not be entertained; and how they lay under an Oak that Night, and the next Morning took their Journey for Me≈øemptronia.

div.p:
PHilonzo and Cruentius being come to the Shepherd's Hou≈øe immediately alighted and knockt at the Door, but the old Shepherd and his Wife being newly gone to Bed, were very unwilling to ri≈øe; at la≈øt the Shepherd hearing them grow more violent in their Knocks, aro≈øe, and looked out of (I cannot ≈øay the Window) but out of a Hole or Cranny, and asked. Who was there; to which Philonzo replied, A couple of Pa≈ø≈øengers which had lo≈øt their Way in the Wood, and by a Dog which we followed brought hither. The Shepherd's Wife which but a little before was awaked out of her Sleep with ≈øighing for the Lo≈øs of her Dog, ≈øtarts out of her Bed and cries, Oh, her dear Cut, and ≈øo runs down and lets in her Dog, and after many Expre≈ø≈øions of in≈øufferable Joy, having entertain ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ her Dog with many a ≈øweet Ki≈øs, ≈øhe went to Bed and ≈ølept very heartily, whil≈øt Philonzo and Cruentius begg'd very earne≈øtly for Entertainment to protect them from a Storm, which they perceived was ha≈øtening upon them;
but all their Intreaties were in vain; for the Shepherd told them, That he and his Wife were abu≈øed not long ≈øince by a Couple that de≈øired to be entertained as they did, and therefore he would not admit them by any means: At la≈øt, when they ≈øaw their Intreaties were in vain, they departed, tru≈øting them≈øelves to the Protection of an Oak, where they had not long repo≈øed, but a great Tempe≈øt of Thunder and Lightning di≈øturbed them of their Re≈øt, ≈øo that they for≈øook the place, as deeming it dangerous to lye there in ≈øuch tempe≈øtuous Weather; ≈øo wandring up and down all Nigt, without any Re≈øt, in the Morning they prepared for their Journey, and being at la≈øt refre≈øhed with the Heat of the Sun, they ≈øpurred chearfully along till they came within View of a (not ≈øtately but) well ≈øcituated Hou≈øe, not far from which, they e≈øpied a beautiful Lady walking ≈øo ≈øolitary, that ≈øhe hardly took notice of her own Thoughts: Philonzo riding towards her, and ≈øurprizing her on a ≈øudden, put her into ≈øuch an Ama≈øement; that for the pre≈øent ≈øhe knew neithre what to do or ≈øay; but Phi-well skill'd in the Rudiments of malicious Impudence, begins to acco≈øt her in this manner:

Madam, quoth he, I very much commend your Choice, you have cho≈øen a plea≈øant Morning, and a ≈øweet Air for your private Meditations. Sir, replied the Lady, the Walk and the Air would be more plea≈øant if you were further from it; I wonder a Knight, as you ≈øeem to be, ≈øhould be ≈øo unadvi≈øed, or rather uncivil, to intrude without Notice or Acquaintance; Sir, if you are noble, ≈øhew it by your Eorbearance. to which replied Philonzo,

Madam, had you been le≈øs Beautiful, I had been le≈øs Ambitious; but, Madam, your Beauty is the Author of my bold Intru≈øion, but I hope you have Goodne≈øs to pardon, as well as I have Infirmities to offend. Sir, quoth the Lady, the Vanity of Court≈øhip hath taught me to di≈ølike a Courtier, I will therefore leave my Walk to your Enjoyment. Nay, quoth Philonzo, I cannot ≈øo ≈øuddenly di≈ømi≈øs you, for your Beauty
has made ≈øuch a Conque≈øt of my Heart, ≈øo either return what your Beauty has robb'd me of, or I mu≈øt be inforced to take it. Sir, quoth the Lady, I neither know your Intent, not Meaning, but I expect you to be civil, therefore wrong not my Expectations. At which Words, Philonzo beckoning to his Brother Cruentine that ≈øtood within ≈øight, pre≈øently with much Rigour and Incivility laid hold on her, and dragg'd her into a Forre≈øt which was within half a Mile, being a≈ø≈øi≈øted by his Brother Cruentine. I need not tell the Reader of the many Tears, the grievous Complaints, the ≈øundry Prayers this poor di≈øte≈ø≈øed Lady made to tho≈øe inhumane Villains, but all to no purpo≈øe: For had not an unexpected Knight pa≈ø≈øed by, who hearing the Shrieks of one in Di≈øtre≈øs, boldly approached to place, where he found the≈øe Villains endeavouring to rob her of her Cha≈øtity, whom they '≈øpying, perceived him to be their Brother, which they left bound in the Wood, ran away, and at la≈øt arrived at Me≈øemptronia, where being come, they pre≈øently went to to their Inn, and ≈øo to Re≈øt, not at the lea≈øt troubled at their barbarous Cruelty; the next Morning approaching, they aro≈øe, and commanded a plentiful Dinner to be provided, and that ≈øuch Company as the City afforded ≈øhould be invited to keep them Company, being Strangers at that Time; to which their Ho≈øt, preferring his own Gain, conde≈øcended, and fore with ≈øent for a Crew of the mo≈øt notorious Cheats the Town could afford, who plau≈øibly treated the new come Gue≈øts, telling them of the many Courti≈øans the City abounded withal, which were pre≈øently ≈øent for, and a great Banquet provided, to the Admiration of the diligently joyful Ho≈øt; but after ≈øome Days of their abode they began to feel a Con≈øumption in their Pockets, which cau≈øed them to con≈øult of their Departure.

div.head: Chap. VII.

argument.p: How Innocentine had his De≈øire in the inchanted Ca≈øtle, with a Promi≈øe to return; how he recovered the Golden Eagle from the Queen of Green Iveyland, and how his Hor≈øe was turned into a Man, who afterwards directed him what to do.

div.p:
AFter Innocentine perceiv'd which Steed it was which the Lady advi≈øed him to reque≈øt, he was very importunate with the Ladies to let him have that Hor≈øe which was laid; to which they replied, Alas, that was the wor≈øt in the Stable, de≈øiring him to make ≈øome other Choice; but he replied, That the other were too good and too lu≈øty for him, in re≈øpect that he was a very bad Hor≈øeman. The Ladies ≈øeeing that
woodcut of man riding horse he would not be denied, endeavoured to enchant him, but their Enchantments could not take Effect, becau≈øe the Hermit's Sword, was a Pre≈øervative. Thus ≈øeeing all their Labour in vain, they made him ≈øwear that he would return again, and he ≈øhould have his De≈øires; but to be ≈øhort, having ≈øwore according to their De≈øires, the Hor≈øe was brought forth, he
leaping upon him, was on a ≈øudden carried to Green Iveyland, and in his Journey overthrew many Knights which waited there to encounter any that ≈øhould approach: But he with his good Sword and Steed made ≈ølight of 'em; then he approached to the Brazen Walls, where he was welcomed with the Roaring of Lions and Dragons, but as he brandi≈øhed his Sword they fell into a dead Sleep, then Innocentine pa≈ø≈øed freely: not long after he came to a Fort which was guarded by Giants, who when they perceived his Approach, pre≈øently came running at him with great Violence, but he no ≈øooner brandi≈øh'd his ≈øword but they fell all a≈øleep. At length, having many more Difficulties, which are now too tedious to relate, he came to the Place where the Queen and the Eagle was: The Queen and her Attendance beholding a Stranger ≈øo near her Pre≈øence, began to rebuke his In≈øolency; but he brandi≈øhing his Sword, the Queen and all her Attendance fell a≈øleep, in≈øomuch that they could not be waked; in the mean time Innocentine alighted and took the Eagle, with no ≈ømall joy, and was departing, but his Hor≈øe would not by any means ≈øtir a Foot from the Pl ‚Ä¢ ce, which made Innocentine in a doubt what to do; but beholding the incomparable Beauty of the Queen, he drew near and ≈øaluted her as ≈øhe ≈ølept, after which, Innocentine cut off a Lock of the Queen's Hair, and left a Lock of his in her Bo≈øom, and then he took a Ring of rich Value from her Finger, and put one of his in the ≈øame place; then finding her Picture about her Neck, he took that off, and ≈øupplied the Place with his own. Having done the≈øe things, he writes the≈øe Lines, and pins them upon the Sleeve of her Garment:
Renowned Queen, what here is done,
Was acted by a Monarch's Son:
But before I could depart,
I took your Eagle, left my Heart:
Accept the Change, and pardon the Abu≈øe;
Virtue whilst you remain, will be in u≈øe.
Having thus done, he mounts his Hor≈øe with the Eagle in his Hand, and was immediately brought to the Forre≈øt where he pre≈øerved the Lady from Ravi≈øhment: His Steed making a Stand at a great River, would not go any further, notwith≈øtanding Innocentine u≈øed all the Skill he could with Switch and Spur, but at la≈øt his Hor≈øe ≈øpake, and bid him forbear, and alight; Innocentine not a little amazed, alighted, then the Hor≈øe began to tell him, he mu≈øt chop off his Head, and throw it into that River, withal bidding him not to be afraid for he intended him no Harm; But, ≈øays he, when you have throw me in, ≈øtand with your Sword by the River, and in what Shape ≈øoever you ≈øee me appear, knock me down again, till I ari≈øe in the Shape of a Man; Innocentine being ≈øomething amazed at this ≈øudden and ≈øtrange Alteration, knew not for the pre≈øent what to do, but after a little pau≈øe, he re≈øolved to do it, which being done, he threw the Head into the River, and it ro≈øe up the fir≈øt time like a Lyon, but he pre≈øently knockt it down, then it ro≈øe up in ≈øeveral other Shapes, but he ≈øtill kept it down, but at la≈øt it aro≈øe like a tall proper Man, and then he helpt it out, which being done; the Man bid him fear nothing but follow his Advice, and give Ear to him, whil≈øt he informed him of ≈øomething which might conduce to his Benefit: I was, ≈øaith he, a Knight in that enchanted Ca≈øtle which you had me out of, and all tho≈øe fair Steeds you ≈øaw, were inchanted Knights; I am likewi≈øe the Husband of that Lady you pre≈øerved from the Violence of your Brothers, which Brothers will meet with you before you come home, with full Re≈øolution to kill you; but fear not, but hide the Ring and Picture, which you had of the Queen, and de≈øire them not to kill you, but tell them you will never di≈øcover them to your Father, then they ≈øhall take away your Eagle and let you go; Thus as you have pre≈øerved me and mine, I will pre≈øerve you and yours.

div.head: Chap. VIII.

argument.p: How Philonzo and Cruentius obtained a counterfeit Eagle in the City of Me≈øemptronia, and returning home met their younger Brother Innocentine, and robb'd him of his Eagle, and what after happened.

div.p:
PHilonzo and Cruentius having ≈øpent mo≈øt of their Money, at la≈øt agreed with ≈øome in the City to get them an Eagle; which they pretended they could do, which was not long effecting, for they got a very great Fowl, the neare≈øt they could like an Eagle, and guilded his Feathers, and brought it to them, which they with much Joy accepted, giving a large Sum for it, and forthwith departed the City; but as they travelled, it was their Fortune to meet their Brother Innocentine carrying an Eagle in a ≈øilver Cage, at the ≈øight whereof their Eagle trembled and dyed; but without the lea≈øt Salute to their Brother, they run upon him, and would have killed him; but he, according to his Advice had hid the Ring and Picture in a private place about him, which they di≈øcover'd not, but took away Cage and Eagle, with full intent to kill him; but he with many pa≈ø≈øionate Expre≈ø≈øions diverted their Intentions, promi≈øing them to become their Servant, and never betray them to his Father: they hearing the≈øe Promi≈øes, ≈øaved his Life, and ≈øo he became their Servant, and they journeyed together; at la≈øt coming home, and carrying their Eagle in Triumph, they were ioyfully entertained; the King embracing the two Elde≈øt, and commanding the Younge≈øt to be immediately put to Death for tho≈øe Lyes which his Brothers had related of him; but Innocentine heartily begg'd of his Father that he might not be put to Death, and ≈øo did his Brothers ≈øeemingly, but that he might be made Inferior to the wor≈øt Servant in the Hou≈øe, to which the King, though, unwilling, agreed: Thus was poor Innocentine, that de≈øerved a ju≈øt Reward, ca≈øt out of his Father's Favour for ever. But it happened that not long after the Queen of Green Ivy-land, hearing where her Eagle
was, came with a great Train to Arragon, and pre≈øented her≈øelf to the King, who was ab≈øolutely cured by the Vertue of the Eagle. The Queen receiving that bountiful Entertainment which her E≈øtate required, asked the King how many Sons he had; to which the King replied, Two; ≈øhe de≈øired ≈øhe might be allowed ≈øo great a Favour as to ≈øee them; immediately they appeared; ≈øo ≈øhe called Philonzo, and asked him if he was the Man that made ≈øo gallant an Attempt for her Eagle; he replied, It was his poor Endeavour that obtained it. Pray, ≈øays ≈øhe, let me ≈øee ≈øome A≈ø≈øurance; did you leave me nothing, nor take nothing from me? No, replied Philonzo. Then, quoth the Queen, you are not the Man; after him was pre≈øented Cruentius, whom the Queen in like manner greeted, but he replied as Philonzo did, That he took nothing from her, nor left any thing with her. The Queen concealing her Anger, told the King that the≈øe My≈øteries pa≈øt her Imaginations; de≈øired the King ingeniou≈øly to tell her if he had no more Sons. Renowned Queen, I mu≈øt confe≈øs I had another Son, which now I own not; I think he may be living among≈øt the mean Servants of my Hou≈øe, but for a Son I own him not. To which the Queen replied, ≈øhe mu≈øt needs ≈øee him; Alas, replied the King, I think him not worthy of my Pre≈øence, much more of ≈øo renowned a Queen as your≈øelf: but to ≈øatisfie your Reque≈øts, he ≈øhall be called; in the mean time the King departed, whil≈øt Innocentine approached the Queen's Pre≈øence, to whom the Queen di≈øcours'd as follows:

Are you the younge≈øt Son of this Royal King, or no? he replied, with a blu≈øhing Countenance, No. What, are you his Servant? he replied, No. Friend, you ≈øpeak very my≈øterou≈øly, di≈øcover thy ≈øelf. Then know, incomparable Lady, that my Father being incens'd again≈øt me, condemn'd me to dye; but by the Reque≈øt of my Brothers I was pre≈øerved, and became a Servant to the wor≈øt of my Father's Servants, contenting my ≈øelf with the≈øe poor Habiliments, which indeed were they as rich as could be imagined, were too mean to be
pre≈øented before ≈øo worthy a Per≈øon, as, Madam, you are; and for my≈øelf, I could tremble into A≈øhes at the ≈øight of ≈øo excellent a Creature as your vertuous ≈øelf; but I ≈øhall remove ≈øo unworthy an Object from your Sight, and crave Licen≈øe to depart. No, replyed the Queen, you ≈øhall not; I have a few que≈øtions to ask you. My Rudene≈øs, mo≈øt unparrall'd Lady, ≈øhall be as obedient to reply, as your Grace ≈øhall be ready to demand, although I am unworthy to be the lea≈øt of your Creatures. The Queen hearing him expre≈øs him≈øelf with ≈øo much Humility, and Excellency of Speech, the King forgetting his Son was there, came ≈øuddenly into the Pre≈øence of Queen, and beholding his Out-ca≈øt, ≈øtarted back; the Queen perceiving it, de≈øir'd the King to yield her ≈øo great a Favour as to ≈øtay to hear her ask his Son two or three Que≈øtions; the King not u≈øing to deny the Reque≈øt of ≈øuch Per≈øons, ≈øate down, whil≈øt the Queen thus expre≈øt her≈øelf to Innocentine: Was it you that took my Eagle from me, pray an≈øwer me without Ceremony? To which he bowing him≈øelf, replyed, Madam, I did. And what Token left you with me, or took from me? Madam, a Lock of your Hair. Where is it? replied the Queen. Next my Heart, Madam, replied Innocentine, and here it is. But what did you leave me? ≈øaid the Queen. A Lock of mine, replied Innocentine. Great Prince, (≈øaid the Queen to the King) and here it is; but pray let your Patience expect my farther Di≈øcour≈øe with him; Come hither, ≈øaid the Queen, to ba≈øhful Innocentine, do you know this Picture and this Ring? Yes, Madam, and I hope your Greatne≈øs knows the≈øe, (≈øhewing her the Picture and Ring which he had took from her.) Come, ≈øays the Queen, give me the Picture, and in≈øtead of the Shadow, take the Sub≈øtance; I am re≈øolved, renowned King, not to depart, till I have made him Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of all I have. Admire it not; for it is nothing but Truth.

The King, like a Man tran≈øported, at fir≈øt thought the Queen to be po≈ø≈øe≈øt of a Frenzy, but after more ≈øerious Debate, found all Truth which ≈øhe had related, and pre≈øently
≈øent for his two Sons, Philonzo and Cruentius, and commands their Heads to be ≈øtruck off; but Innocentine ≈øeconded with his incomperable Lady, per≈øwaded his Father to ≈øave their Lives, and bani≈øh them; which the King, though unwillingly, con≈øented to, after which he imbraced his Son, and told him, in Requital of his great Abu≈øes, he would ≈øettle his Kingdom upon him. The Queen joyful to ≈øee the King imbrace his Son, de≈øired the King that hereafter he would plea≈øe to own her as his obedient Daughter. So Innocentine and the Queen were ≈øhortly after married, and departed into their own Country of Ivy land.

figure.figDesc: woodcut of prince and princess joining hands, several other people present
